messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 51 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Immersed boundary parametrizations for full waveform inversion

Paper Abstract: 

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 51 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 51"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The seismic inverse problem as a sequence of before stack migrations",
        "Inversion of seismic reflection data in the acoustic approximation",
        "A tutorial on the adjoint method for inverse problems",
        "Full Seismic Waveform Modelling and Inversion",
        "An overview of full-waveform inversion in exploration geophysics",
        "Comparisons for waveform inversion, time domain or frequency domain?",
        "Sound-speed and attenuation imaging of breast tissue using waveform tomography of transmission ultrasound data",
        "Frequency domain ultrasound waveform tomography: breast imaging using a ring transducer",
        "3d frequency-domain ultrasound waveform tomography breast imaging",
        "Full-waveform inversion imaging of the human brain",
        "Guided wave tomography based on full-waveform inversion",
        "Investigation of the reconstruction accuracy of guided wave tomography using full waveform inversion",
        "Corrosion detection with ray-based and full-waveform guided wave tomography",
        "Full waveform inversion for ultrasonic nondestructive testing",
        "Modeling of ultrasound tomographic imaging for non-destructive inspection of underwater structures",
        "Multi-parameter reconstruction of velocity and density using ultrasonic tomography based on full waveform inversion",
        "Development of low-frequency phased array for imaging defects in concrete structures",
        "Weld defect detection using ultrasonic phased arrays",
        "Ultrasonic imaging of irregularly shaped notches based on elastic reverse time migration",
        "Point cloud-based elastic reverse time migration for ultrasonic imaging of components with vertical surfaces",
        "Ultrasonic arrays for non-destructive evaluation: A review",
        "Ultrasonic methods for non-destructive testing",
        "Sizing of flaws using ultrasonic bulk wave testing: A review",
        "Waveform-based geometrical inversion of obstacles",
        "Shape identification of scatterers using a time-dependent adjoint method",
        "The p-Version of the Finite Element and Finite Cell Methods",
        "Introduction to Elastic Wave Propagation",
        "Gmsh: A 3-d finite element mesh generator with built-in pre- and post-processing facilities",
        "SciPy 1.0: Fundamental Algorithms for Scientific Computing in Python",
        "Numerical Optimization",
        "The adjoint method in seismology: I. theory",
        "The adjoint method in seismology—: Ii. applications: traveltimes and sensitivity functionals",
        "On solution of some boundary value problems on high performance computers by fictitious domain method.",
        "The finite cell method for three-dimensional problems of solid mechanics",
        "An isogeometric design-through-analysis methodology based on adaptive hierarchical refinement of nurbs, immersed boundary methods, and t-spline cad surfaces",
        "Cutfem: Discretizing geometry and partial differential equations",
        "Analysis in computer aided design: Nonlinear isogeometric b-rep analysis of shell structures",
        "The aggregated unfitted finite element method for elliptic problems",
        "Efficient Finite Element Methodology Based on Cartesian Grids: Application to Structural Shape Optimization",
        "The shifted boundary method for embedded domain computations. part i: Poisson and stokes problems",
        "The shifted boundary method for embedded domain computations. part ii: Linear advection–diffusion and incompressible navier–stokes equations",
        "High-order cut finite elements for the elastic wave equation",
        "Numerical analysis of lamb waves using the finite and spectral cell methods",
        "Finite and spectral cell method for wave propagation in heterogeneous materials",
        "Moment fitted cut spectral elements for explicit analysis of guided wave propagation",
        "Numerical integration of discontinuities on arbitrary domains based on moment fitting",
        "Higher-order accurate integration of implicit geometries",
        "The finite cell method with least squares stabilized nitsche boundary conditions",
        "Ghost penalty",
        "Condition number analysis and preconditioning of the finite cell method",
        "Stability and conditioning of immersed finite element methods: analysis and remedies"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 51 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Immersed boundary parametrizations for full waveform inversion, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
